@Mitra (My last post here)

"South Korea did not manage fully to reverse the trend until its GDP per person had reached about $12,000."

PS I forgot to add:

The per capita income has (a little over) doubled for the European countries between 1990 and 2011

UK: 16,600 (1990) ====> 38,140 (2011) (2.3 times)
France: 20,090 (1990) ====> 42,420 (2011) (2.1 )
Germany: 20,630 (1990) ====> 43,980 (2011) (2.13)

I've left Hungary out because in 1890, it was part of a much larger empire.

That means the 1890 per capita income in 2011 dollars was:

United Kingdom: $9,326
France: $4,645
Germany: $5,893

None were near 12,000 that the article mentions, yet their sex-ratios (females per 1000 males) were:

England 1045
Scotland 1076
France 1003
Germany 1043

South Korea, whose 2011 per capita income is $31,200 has sex ratio 1000.

Clearly cultural matters play a role here.

The Republicans remain slaves to Grover Norquist, selling their minds and judgment to one self-interested lobbyist. And selling out their souls and American democracy to a plutocracy which betrays the egalitarian ideals of the nation's founders.

By any international comparison, the American government is under-funded. A time of mass unemployment is time for true stimulative spending, including new attention to the 22 per cent of American children living in poverty, mostly in a deep poverty utterly destructive to the lives and futures of 15 million children.

Let the Bush tax cuts expire. And then reinstate them for the bottom 90 per cent, not 98 per cent. Use the new revenues to invigorate demand through direct spending on decaying infrastructure and increased fiancial support for American families with incomes under $80,000.

Another Republican fixation is the national debt. The country with the lowest public debt as a percentage of g.d.p. is Liberia, a country founded as a home for freed American slaves. Perhaps with its astoundingly low debt and low taxes, Liberia could be a home for a new generation of American slaves--the blind followers of Grover Norquist.

“Social Security has nothing to do with the deficit. Social Security is totally funded by the payroll tax levied on employer and employee. If you reduce the outgo of Social Security that money would not go into the general fund to reduce the deficit. It would go into the Social Security trust fund. So, Social Security has nothing to do with balancing a budget or erasing or lowering the deficit.” – Ronald Reagan

Sen. Sanders: Ronald Reagan was Right
http://www.sanders.senate.gov/newsroom/news/?id=ed9fd80f-e441-478a-b67a-...

The voices of doom on Social Security are wrong. Absolutely nothing has to be done in the near-term. The program has a separate stream of financing, it can pay all benefits for the next 25 years, and has not added one penny to the deficit. Eliminating or raising the $110K cap on the payroll tax will make the program solvent for decades.

Hands off! It’s an earned benefit, not an entitlement.

No cuts to Medicare and Medicaid. Affordable health care through Medicare for all is easy to achieve. Congress simply needs to remove two words from the Medicare law: “over 65.”

Deficits would turn into surpluses if we end corporate welfare for the military-industrial-security complex and the medical-industrial complex; return to a progressive tax code; end tax loopholes, subsidies, and other giveaways to corporations; enact a modest Wall Street speculation tax; and put Americans back to work by investing in infrastructure, clean energy, R&D and education.

RLS: "Hands off! It’s an earned benefit, not an entitlement."

That's exactly why retirement should not be trusted to politicians who make Bernie Madoff look like a saint. Yes, retirees have paid several times more than they should have to to get their given SS benefit but that doesn't change the fact that the money is gone. Yes, they paid plenty into Medicare to pay for their old age healthcare but that doesn't change the fact that the money is gone. Social Security and Medicare are robbing millions of retirees of hundreds of thousands of dollars. It was never about helping retirees. It was about cheating workers from the start.
You're right, of course, and so was Reagan. But saying something good about Reagan will not get you any support from the Krugman claque.

The amount of earnings subject to the Social Security payroll tax is going up to $113,700 for 2013. See, www.ssa.gov/oact/cola/cbb/html. Back in 1983, I believe it was Alan Greenspan,among others, who made sure Boomers would pay for the Social Security insurance benefits by increasing the tax rate for employee and employers from 5.6% to the current 6.2%. So RLS, you are right, Social Security benefits are fully funded for at least 21 years, probably longer as many Boomers during this Great Recession are applying for benefits "early" i.e. before age 66, thereby reducing their overall old age benefits in the long run.

“He wants to curb the increased costs of Medicare and Social Security by ‘bending the curve’ of those benefits.”

Let’s repeat it one more time: Social Security does not add to the deficit―it’s impossible by law. The program’s funds are separate from the general budget. It must pay its own way.

We can rein in our health care costs by adopting single-payer Medicare for all. The US is the only country that relies on for-profit insurance companies.

“If you want to get rid of the deficit and have a balanced budget, the number one way to do that is universal healthcare, that gets the business of healthcare off the backs of small business owners, so they’re not diverted from running their businesses, and brings down costs.” – David Cay Johnston, tax columnist for Reuters

Another common sense approach to deficit reduction is to end corporate welfare for the military-industrial-security complex. The annual budget is $1 trillion. Reducing this wasteful spending by half would allow us to bring down our deficit and make investments in the productive economy.

The biggest military in the world cannot defend itself if its infrastructure is crumbling and its people are not healthy or educated. Infrastructure projects create 40 percent more jobs per dollar than spending on the military, health care creates 70 percent more jobs, and education creates 240 percent more jobs.
